urn:contentItem:5SBT-5XD1-JB20-G11J-00000-00IHS Markit Ltd at Barclays Americas Select Franchise Conference - Final2018-05-15T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:00:58ZLexisNexis051518a11497529.729IHS Markit Ltd at Barclays Americas Select Franchise Conference - Final

Corporate Participants

* Lance Uggla

IHS Markit Ltd. - Chairman & CEO

Conference Call Participants

* Manav Shiv Patnaik

Barclays Bank PLC, Research Division - Director & Lead Research Analyst

Presentation

MANAV SHIV PATNAIK, DIRECTOR & LEAD RESEARCH ANALYST, BARCLAYS BANK PLC, RESEARCH DIVISION: All right, guys. Good morning. Thank you everyone for being here. My name is Manav Patnaik. I'm Barclays' Business Information and Professional Services Analyst. I think you'll see me for the rest of the morning here.

But to start off here, we have Lance Uggla, Chairman and CEO of IHS Markit. So thank you for being here, Lance.

LANCE UGGLA, CHAIRMAN & CEO, IHS MARKIT LTD.: Thank you.

MANAV SHIV PATNAIK: I'm obviously going to do a fireside chat here. If there any questions in the middle, if you want to interrupt, please, just raise your hand and we're happy to do that.

Questions and Answers

MANAV SHIV PATNAIK: So maybe just to kick it off, Lance, it's been about 2 years since the IHS Markit deal came together. You're now running the show on your own. Maybe just some quick, sort of, 2-year thoughts on how you think the deal's going so far.

LANCE UGGLA: Okay. So really, Jerre and I had the fortune -- Jerre Stead, the CEO of IHS when we merged, had the pleasure of meeting and setting out a plan together, including laying out the management team. And really, we did that together. And I think we did it in a way that allowed us to have a really simple transition. And so today, 2 years on, and Jerre transitioning out at the end of last year, the company is in a good trajectory and it's one that we laid out together, so no real big changes. I've just finished a 4-week trip seeing customers and shareholders, we're finishing this up today. And I think we met about 100 customers and shareholders over that 4-week period. So I have a good pulse for our customer base, using our products. The markets we're in are all fairly robust and consistent. Global economies ex some geopolitical risks are in good shape. And I feel we've got a set of shareholders that are now aligned with the story that we've laid out, which is the mid-single-digit growth. We can consistently generate the 100 basis points of margin and deliver double digit earnings growth. And I think if we just stick to that and don't get away from ourselves, we've got a great story.

MANAV SHIV PATNAIK: And in terms of your customer trip that you just did, I guess, what is the feedback in terms of the value add or the synergy of having the market with the IHS pieces. Was there -- like how do you lay in that discussion with these customers?

LANCE UGGLA: Right. Well, I think the -- really, we looked at -- well, first of all, you don't want to end up in a company that's just 3 divisions with no sense of purpose together. So really there's 3 pieces, nonfinancial pieces, that really tie our company together. So the first was the account management layer we put in right across the group. So one company had account management, the other company didn't. We now have an 80-person strong account management team that is allowing us to really start to push the revenue synergies, which are an important part of our transaction. And this is a very, very detailed approach. Weekly reporting goes across all the business entities. And I'd say about 70% of those synergies are all about delivering IHS legacy content into financial market participants, which are great consumers of information and quite large vendors in terms of finding that needle in a haystack to either buy something, sell something, advise on something, develop a proposal on something. The other 30%, data management, credit analysis, other more financial market strengths brought to the corporate customers. So the first thing that pulls us together is that common account management structure, and I work very closely with that team. The second thing that draws us together is starting to pull the data sets together. And I hate to use all the buzzwords, AI, data science, all the things that you're hearing probably in every meeting because really, to me, I just look at it as math and scenarios, using cheap storage and a lot of compute power. And that's the thing that's changed. If I go back 15 years ago, we're using math and scenarios, it just took us all night to run them, and today it's much, much quicker. So the second piece that pulls us together is a common data science team across the whole firm, working on a lot of the new issues -- sorry, new developments and innovations that also drive some revenue synergies of the transaction. And then the third and final place, pull your operational teams together in a way to drive additional cost synergies as well as to just organize yourself long term for incremental margin, as you can use technology to drive further efficiencies. Those are the 3 layers that -- beside shared services, HR, legal, PR, IR, those are the 3 areas where we're really trying to build a single IHS Markit, allowing each of the divisions to use their competitive edge, which is always content and subject matter experts, leveraging technology, producing ideas for our customers. And that's -- it is a real simple formula.

MANAV SHIV PATNAIK: All right, that's helpful. Maybe if you're going to start on the segment, so if you can start with energy. I think oil price is in the s$70 right now. I believe your guidance was somewhere in the $55 to $60 range, I'm not sure how directly it impacts your guidance. But just some thoughts there. Are you seeing any timely with your customer visits? Are your energy customers, all of a sudden, feeling that much incrementally better? Or how should we think about that?

LANCE UGGLA: Right. So -- and you can get most of these interviews online. But this year, our CERAWeek conference, which is a real thought leadership event around the energy markets, it had some 700 to 1,000 more people than the previous year. Its revenues were up double digit, and it really was a great event. And you could feel a shifting optimism. So definitely, there is some optimism around the energy markets and the customers. Our energy business is really split 60:40, 65:35 upstream and mid-downstream. The mid-downstream, which includes chemicals, great business; power; gas; renewables; coal; all our pricing in news assets that would compete against the Platts or an Argus, that grew at 5% to 7% right through the downturn. So if you just think about that piece, very stable, very recurring, lots of data, lots of subject matter experts. And if you put a consistent growth on that, 35%, 40% at 5% to 7%, that's 2% to 3% growth across the division, and we called out low single digits for 2018 based on our $55, $65 oil price. If you go to upstream, upstream definitely has an impact when there's additional CapEx, there's additional use of Markit, IHS Markit services. So we do benefit from a higher energy price, but not -- the swing is not as much as you might feel. And I know, when you're talking to a hedge fund, they look at oil price and think that IHS Markit's a good play. My view is that if you take the downturn where CapEx was slashed 50%-plus percent and look at 2016, '17, legacy IHS was down minus 5%, minus 10% on that division, it's just not the wild swings with energy price. Because really what you're looking at, historically, the retrenchment was, we're not going to be doing any exploration offshore Brazil, we don't need that data set, but we still need all the other data sets we use from IHS Markit. We're trenching from North Sea, we don't need that data set. So as energy companies go back into those marketplaces, they will take additional services and subscriptions, and of course, we'll see a little bit of growth from that. I also think one thing's changed. When the energy company thinks about going back into the North Sea, I think it's a much more well-thought, careful decision versus $100 oil price, where everybody exploring in 3 continents and really a much more expensive chase for energy. I think this time you're going to see a much more careful approach. The profits come at a lower energy price and a lot of the fat's been taken out of the industry. So therefore, when they do take those subscriptions on to go back into offshore Africa, Brazil, North Sea oil sands, I think what you're going to see is a much more consistent and stable revenue stream. And so when I look at that low single digits, I think, "Hey, that's a great number for '18. It's got upside into '19. And if you're investing in us long term, you know that, that mid-single-digits overall growth can produce double digit earnings growth with the margin expansion." And I think that is a really good way to think about our company. Just don't -- you don't need to think that we need to do 4%, 5%, 6% in energy, but if it comes as we go into '19, great, it will set us up well for next year.

MANAV SHIV PATNAIK: You talked earlier about how the financial customers are great consumers of data, but they're also pretty volatile. And so I think Verisk, in their call, talked about a big ID client, it sounded like it was Deutsche Bank getting out and hurting their business. What's your exposure to financial customers, I guess, with that risk, maybe on the sales side, like the banks or whatever it is?

LANCE UGGLA: Yes. I think we've got an opportunity that Wood Mac maybe doesn't have. One, when we merged the 2 companies, the one place where IHS wasn't penetrated was the financial markets on the energy side. And a couple good drivers there. One, you've merged 2 companies, one that has deep financial market presence globally with 5,000-ish customers and a lot of C-Suite access. So definitely we have access to pitch our products, which is always #1. Can you get through the door? Secondly, we have deeper data sets than anybody else in that space. But financial market participants want -- it's not so much the depth of the data, it's the data with the subject matter experts and available to support decision-making and transactions. And so that's an area of the market that we're going after. So we're chasing to get our share of that. And as market participants look at their renewals and their position in that space, I think we have a chance to grow, and we're very focused on building our presence into the financial markets in growing that. So I don't worry about us losing much because our position there is quite small right now.

MANAV SHIV PATNAIK: Got it. And then in terms of the innovation on the energy side, I mean, particularly, we talked about Vantage a lot and Wood Mac, Abertis talked about replatforming their whole business and then investing a lot in their margins. Like is -- but I think the energy margins are low 40s and so how do -- how does that innovation pipeline look like in the energy side?

LANCE UGGLA: Yes. So for us, the innovation that we're generating on the energy side -- and again our platform is new. Vantage was a platform that was freshly developed within IHS, and we continue to build that out now as IHS Markit, whereas Wood Mac established older platform probably needs a freshening up. So I think our position and our competitive edge is to leverage the freshness and newness of our platform and develop it with data and data analytics and predictive analytics, scenario analysis, asset valuations, with a much more easy access, great, strong compute power and a little bit of data science as we would say in today's world. And I think that's where we're going to have an opportunity to have ourselves positioned much better with financial market customers looking to value portfolio assets or advise on assets. So I think we have a little bit of upside there. Again, I don't think financial markets for IHS Markit is the game changer in our energy strategy. But I don't see downside there, I see incremental upside.

MANAV SHIV PATNAIK: Got it. We were at the CERAWeek that you mentioned, and there was a clear -- there was a noticeable uptick in the number of financial attendees there, to your point on the synergies. Is there a lot to think about on the reverse? So the market products to IHS customers? Or how do you think about the reverse synergy, I suppose?

LANCE UGGLA: Right. Yes. So what I found at CERAWeek was really the first time -- I think IHS Markit, we looked at CERAWeek and said, "This is a great energy platform." But it's also a platform for the company to use and leverage its global position across mobility, technology, financial market participants and energy, and find those places where those intersections existed. So you probably saw when you were there a whole floor of technology and innovation around tech. But what was really interesting is, is the presence of Amazon. So Bill Vass shows up and has a head of energy with him. Diane Greene comes, speaks from Google Cloud. A few weeks later, there's an announcement they've hired a head of energy from BP. Microsoft Azure is there. So we've got the presence of big tech providers. Why are they there? Because they want to host our content and they want the energy companies to select them to host their content, which gives us those future opportunities for our product synergies. So I think on the -- on that side, we saw the intersections of technology, energy, mobility. We had Mary Barra there and some other technical analysts from the financial markets around mobility and looking at the supply and demand characteristics into the power grid from all aspects of energy. And then we saw -- and the connected car and the data needs and then we got the financial market participants. And the financial market participants are there because they want to finance things. They want the customer relationships, and they want to be able to build strategy around that. So we really felt the company coming together as a single unit, working together to get the best out of this energy conference. Now within the financial market product base, legacy Markit did a couple of things really well. 200-plus big financial market data customers, when I say data customers, using our technology just to organize data to give it some providence and to be able to organize themselves to feed the many systems downstream. What's interesting is energy market participants, large ones, are also big consumers of data. They have data across -- well, now with the Internet of Things, you've got a lot of sensors out in the field, producing a lot of data. They buy a lot of data from the marketplace, whether it's from us or others. And you start to have a real organizational challenge to deliver that data into your risk and control systems, and we have a great tech layer for that. We've now sold that, I think, 8 times another 3 or 4 opportunities in the pipeline. And these are $5 million-plus sales, real synergies that are going the other way. We also -- in the energy market downturn, a lot of private company exposure. Private companies need a different type of credit analysis in terms of looking at their portfolio and potential credit losses. And again, being experts in analytics and financial market pricing, we've been able to help there, especially around derivative portfolios and small company credit exposures across the energy landscape, and there's also been synergies there. So a little less going that way, but some nice shoots of progress and ones that give me optimism that we've got a lot more to come. We did reaffirm our $35 million of synergies this year. We said $10 million last-year, we ended the year at a 12 run rate, which is a little bit better in run rate, but in terms of actual, we're a little bit off of the $10 million. I think we said that at the end of last year. But with good momentum as we went into the second half. And this year, we've reaffirmed $35 million, lots of opportunity in the pipeline, and I don't see us missing that at all. 100 is another step up in '19, we haven't said anything about that, but I think we've got great momentum.

MANAV SHIV PATNAIK: And one of the other opportunities, I think, you had called out early in the call was the MiFID, right? Using the, I guess, the IHS research capabilities to try and take advantage of that. Can you just talk about that positive, but also are you seeing any negatives on the market side of the business?

LANCE UGGLA: Well, I think when investment managers start paying for research, it's interesting. I was with a top energy bank and you probably could tell me numbers for Barclays as well, but -- and I said, "Well, how many real analysts do you have at energy?" The number might have been 20 analysts. I said "How many analysts do you think IHS Markit has across our divisions?" He said, "I don't know, a couple hundred." I said, "How about 1,700." And he went, "You got to be joking." And it's detailed analysis, on every dot of the I, every cross of the T. And it's almost like a firehose of research that comes out of a firm like ours. So does that work for financial market participants in the buy side? No, it needs to be tailored. So the biggest task, I have to say, is packaging the research up, so it can be sold the right way. There's no -- you can't walk in to -- a top $1 trillion asset manager or a $10 billion hedge fund and say, "Let us have $0.5 million or $1 million for our research package." They don't want to spend that. What they want to do is, "We want to look at your solar tech, we want everything on solar tech." That's $50,000 a year, happy as Larry. And you can do those types of sales many times over. But give us all your tech research and it's just way too much. So again, this to me is just great opportunity. So we now have put Adrian Beale in charge of our combined research effort into the buy side. He's ex-Goldman. And we have paired him with actually a buy side research expert from the old Hudson Street to actually package and position the sale of our product. Tom Conigliaro is his name. And they're based in Houston and New York, and they're packaging all the research to sell in. I think MiFID II plays well. One, because we have real specialist. And if somebody's going to pay something, they want to pay for something unique. Subject matter experts, unique content, real specialized data, so I think we got to -- again, it's -- I look at all of this as upside to our business, as usual. And its strategy, it's blocking and tackling, it's doing the things we have to do to be great. And we've got great people doing that. So I think that's showing up in our progress.

MANAV SHIV PATNAIK: Got it. And with the rest of the Markit business, it sounds like the index business is doing well with AUMs going up, volatility is good for processing, the data business is growing, is there anything to call out in that business to keep an eye on other than just more of the same?

LANCE UGGLA: Right. Well, I like that some -- I think it was a BCG partner that said to me, "Half of growth is showing up to the markets you're in and delivering your company." And we're lucky we're in good markets right now. So when I look at the index market, whether you look at S&P, McGraw-Hill, you look at LSE and FTSE, you look at MSCI, it's many years of growth, growing into the passive equity markets for ETFs and benchmarks and index plays. What you're seeing over the last few years is that same growth coming to the fixed income asset class, and really, they are the big -- the MSCIs and the McGraw-Hills and the FTSEs of fixed income are ourselves in Bloomberg with the Barclays Agg. So those are the 2 big index players, and we're getting the outsized growth there. And I really think that's many, many years to come. Fixed income's a much bigger asset class. It includes alternatives. It includes loans. It includes a whole bunch of things, where the growth of that marketplace is -- it's just starting. And the percentage of ETFs and passive investment in fixed income versus equities, it's negligible. So I think there's great growth there. That's just one piece though of our franchise. We're not as narrowly focused. So then you start going across, you know it's a good market if you produce a lot of -- and price a lot of indices. In fixed income, you have to produce the data. The data doesn't come from an exchange, so we have a factory. We have to produce those -- the pricing, and of course, the 2 drive growth together and those have been good, strong growers for us. There's still a propensity to outsource costs. Financial markets are always looking at costs. And I think one of the changes that I'm seeing, that I've also seen some good headlines recently that make me believe that we have good upside here as well, is asset managers are feeling cost pressures. And if that's the case, we're the type of firm that helps groups of financial market participants bring their cost structure down and it's an area where we're quite good at. Processing, I hate to say it, it's -- it really is -- it's $170 million or so market serve, negative 5%, plus 5%. It's now not hugely significant over the whole piece but, of course, does have volatility. And parts of volatility, sometimes, come with increased volume and sometimes smaller size. We're paid by the ticket, so potentially, there's some upside there. But equally, we've seen in the past those numbers can be hard to forecast and it really is volume-based. But I think we're in good markets and we're getting our share and maybe sometimes a little extra.

MANAV SHIV PATNAIK: Okay. Before we go into the auto business, maybe -- I'm not sure what the impact would be, but I'm talking about Brexit basically. You're headquartered here. You live here. Do you see any impact a couple of years later on the business? Or do you have to have backup plans, like all the banks and everyone seem to be doing?

LANCE UGGLA: I'd say there's only -- there's 2 or 3 small impacts I've felt. One, I've felt some people working in London have decided they want to work in Amsterdam, Dublin, Paris, Frankfurt, Milan, Munich, like we really do have a nice footprint around Europe with great offices and individuals feel any -- compelled to work in any of our continental offices, so be it. In today's modern world, that's not an issue. So -- but that's a handful of people. We have no reason why we have to. We offer services that don't require a financial passporting and, therefore, we can operate and sell our products from wherever we'd like. So I don't feel any pressure. I definitely feel that currency and the total cost of employment here in the U.K. looks a little lower vis-Ã -vis other big global centers now just because of where the currency is at the moment. Whatever, it's 1.35. And that -- that's a bit of a benefit and that doesn't hurt us, but because we have a big cost base here and we sell in -- mainly in U.S. dollars. So I guess -- I just -- hey, I'm here. I love being here. I think this is a great city to live in. I don't want to live anywhere else. And I think Brexit's -- this is a long term -- a long game that plays out over many, many years. And yes, it's going to have some little short-term impacts, but I don't see anybody changing course.

MANAV SHIV PATNAIK: Okay, that's fair. So maybe we can just switch to the auto business. It's been your best performing division for quite some time. Maybe just a quick 1-minute on what data and what you own in the auto business because I think people understand energy, I think they knew Markit pretty well because you were a public company before. But maybe just a quick brief on what's the core of the auto and why you're growing high single or double digits in there?

LANCE UGGLA: Right. What was interesting is, is on this road show somebody asked me if I was going to leave IHS Markit. I guess you would -- you'd -- and you could have one division, what would it be? Would it be financial markets because that's where you came from and know it best or would it be automotive because it has such great growth? I said, "No, no, in fact, it'd be energy." And he looked at me and go, "Why would it be energy?" I guess, what I'd say with energy is deepest customer relationships of any franchise I've ever seen. It really is C-Suite access everywhere. And that puts you in a place to do business. And so therefore, I look at our energy franchise and I go, wow, what an exciting franchise, plus it's a real exciting market. And I don't come from an energy background but exploration, changes in demands on power grids, people wanting to be fresh and renewable and out of coal, and we work in both those areas. New technologies and solar and wind, hydrogen conversion, all sorts of things going on in the energy space and a lot of demand and we have great assets. Financial markets, hey, we're one of the -- we're a content player, we're not the television set. We're not Bloomberg or Thomson Reuters or FactSet. I look at that, and I go TVs, networks. We're one of the networks. We can plug-in anywhere, and I think we got a great franchise. We -- we've got a very entrepreneurial, a real gritty team, I'd say, that kind of gets in the corners. It's only 15 years old, but it's kind of made a place for itself. And I love that. Automotive, amazing set of diversified assets with real large addressable markets that we're just starting to attack. And it's not SARS. I never have a discussion about SARS. So what are those assets? Answering your question. It's really 6 or 7 assets that you should think about and think about subscription-based not linked to SARS and think about new content creation that's feeding new addressable markets. Those are the 2 things we do. And I wish I could take credit for any of the past acquisitions of Polk, with CARFAX and CARPROOF. Definitely, front and center with Masterminds, but let me tell you how they all come together and why I feel that, that high single digit revenue growth is there for the next 3 to 5 years anyways. So if you go to -- let's start first with the old IHS Automotive, the whole supply chain and OEM forecasting. That's subscription-based. I'd tell you on this trip, I was in to see some of the auto companies. It is deep, strategic relationships where we have large teams working with the OEMs. There's 17 OEMs, and we're engaged in their whole forecasting and building out their plans, and they need us. And our teams are really strong and they've been engaged for a long time. It's subscription-based. It's not tied to auto sales. Good business. We're well positioned there. We then have registration data. That's the old Polk asset. That describes every car in the garage, across the U.S. going back to Henry Ford. Now that asset is very helpful to drive recall. Now recall's a little bit lumpy, but there are regular recalls every year. And when there is one, we have a data set that helps execute that. And because we have such great history, it's really -- it's nicely moated because of the decades of history. So that's a nice combination. And then we built out, again off the registration data, a whole admissions -- this product called VPaC, again, subscription basis, it helps the OEMs report into the regulatory bodies total admissions. So that's a set of businesses. Subscription has a bit of price, well positioned. Now you get to the other bits. So CARFAX, deep vehicle history reporting, just met $20 billion records. It's one of those things where we see all of our friends talking about their kids, their neighbors, themselves building their new app and they say, "I'm going to build this great travel app. And if I build this app and I get thousands of people coming. And those people are going to be describing themselves, and of course, we're going to create data." CARFAX with vehicle history reporting and 65 million CARFAX users, they have that. Vehicle history reporting was the foundation of CARFAX. So you'd start off and you go, "Yes, but it must be maturing." It is maturing in terms of that piece of the business, but subsequently, CARFAX said, "Let's go into the used car listing business. Okay. And used car listings will be the one chasing the Autotraders, the Cars.com and everybody. And we'll fully integrate vehicle history reporting with used car listings. Double digit growth market for us." Next, geez, we know everything about used cars and value of used cars, the accident history on them, we've got everything on the cars. I wonder if lenders and insurers would like that data, double digit growth market. We know all the dealers and service lane is a great place, we should think about that in the future around myCARFAX. So park that for a moment. You then get our acquisition of Masterminds. Masterminds on the dealer floor with only a thousand dealers compared to tens of thousands of dealers that CARFAX has full penetration as well with CARPROOF in Canada, full penetration. So again, introduction and activity is half the sales process. Get on the floor, get a chance to sell something. So Masterminds, we're growing from 1,000 rooftops to 5,000, 10,000, larger. And then like CARFAX, we'll take it to Canada, take it to Europe and have nice growth parameters. But Masterminds is a small, light AI tool, working on the dealer floor to help retention. So sales for keep, retain customers and get them into another. You're in a Mercedes, get you in another Mercedes. Now what do we have that nobody else has? We got this other data set called registration data over here. The registration data describes all the customers. If Manav and I are the Mercedes dealers, then the front row will have Mercedes and everybody else has Audis, BMWs and Lexus. We now know who all you are, that allows us to do what's called conquest and go after, not just retention of these customers but conquest of others, growth engine for our assets. And then the final growth engine with a big -- and that's -- those are big, addressable markets when you lay out the numbers against them. And it's all kind of used car activities. So we've got new car subscriptions, used car growth, not so much SARS-related. So the final bit is, is that the registration data now plays into a new media component, which is large growth, which is the digital marketing. And the digital marketing to go after incentives and to go after those advertising dollars, which are billions, that we have the feed that allows us to target the right ad at the right person because we have the detail of the car in the garage and the second car in the garage, which is very descriptive. So our digital ad revenues are growing off of our registration data. When I couple all that together, I can't find a nonhigh single digit, whether it's 7, 8, 9, 10. My view is, is we can't be that detailed, but I think high single digits there, mid-single digits in financial markets and low single digits in energy, that's something I can say confidently and that's kind of what we're doing. And if anything, people would say, "You're at the higher end of that. What's next?" I say, "Just -- it's half a year. Let's focus on the base story and then grow from there."

MANAV SHIV PATNAIK: Right. So last question in just a minute or so we have left is capital allocation. OPIS was a good deal. AMM sounds like it's a good deal, but I would say they were more midsize-ish. Like is that more of what we should expect or our ambition's greater than that?

LANCE UGGLA: I think we've said -- one thing I would say is don't expect any transformational deal. You're not going to wake up and see some big merger of equals or anything transformational. And I think that's a story that I'm very confident that we've got so much to do with what we're doing, finishing the integration, getting things done. I've said bolt-on acquisitions, both Jerre and I said those will be part of our course where we see accretive to revenue growth or also opportunity for costs or a combination of both. I will do some bolt-ons and bolt-ons are smaller. And then we're going to always look at the assets we have and make sure that the assets we have are consistent with the 4% to 6% growth story. And of course, over time, we want to shift that growth story -- well, either maintain that growth story with a strong foundation on the lower side of it with opportunity to invest and grow above it or any changes in that portfolio should be accretive to our top line growth. And there, there's addressable markets around all our businesses, of course, we'd like to grow into and those are the types of assets we would always look up.

MANAV SHIV PATNAIK: Got it. Well, we'll just leave it there in the interest of time. So thank you so much, Lance, for being here. Appreciate it.

LANCE UGGLA: Thanks. Thanks, Manav. Thank you very much.

urn:contentItem:5KKK-65J1-F05M-K18N-00000-00iJet lands first big customer for its internet-of-things technology2016-08-31T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:00:58ZLexisNexisiJet lands first big customer for its internet-of-things technologyAndrew McIntosh

As a former U.S. Navy pilot and a current pilot of Boeing 757 and 767 jets, John Schramm has experienced that unnerving feeling.

There's a warning in the cockpit indicating abnormal engine vibrations. Yet those vibrations were intermittent and not actually captured or recorded by the snap shot of data that his own aircraft's systems were sending back to Earth every two hours using conventional aerospace technology.

The result: nobody on the ground was seeing on their computers what the pilots were seeing in the cockpit.

Now, iJet Technologies Inc., the emerging Seattle company that Schramm leads as chief executive, hopes that will change as the world enters the e-enabled airplane era.

iJet has developed its own special software, to be installed onboard airliners, to help connect with ground-based systems to monitor and improve an airline's operational efficiency.

"We are e-enabling legacy airplanes like Boeing 757s, 737s and Airbus A320s, but our products can also add value even on new aircraft, as well," said Schramm, a Delta Air Lines pilot who also has an MBA from Emory University.

iJet's is not your typical technology startup: its small team of skilled software developers are working side by side with veteran aerospace professionals and pilots to develop its solutions.

"Lots of Navy pilots like to say they are pilots during Friday night at the Officers Club, but in my experience not all Navy pilots like being pilots when you have a 2:30 a.m. launch into nasty weather in your fifth month of being gone from home. Early-stage companies are somewhat the same," Schramm said. "They sound cool in the bar and to friends, but they are really not the right place for a lot of folks, so make good choices (on hires) early and correct them fast if you're wrong."

iJet has already has scored a contract coup. Its first customer is Icelandair, an internationally respected though smaller national airline.

iJet has also snared a second airline customer, whose identity remains under wraps.

"Our aim is to enter the market with an innovative early adopter like Icelandair. We're very fortunate that they've chosen to work with us," Schramm said.

Icelandair has made headlines for innovative deals before, such as a partnership with Icelandic music stars Sigur Rós, who debuted her "Valtari" album exclusively onboard Icelandair's planes months before her album was released in stores, and Björk, whose 2011 "Biophilia" album was also released on Icelandair jets.

Already, Schramm says development tests have shown Icelandair managers on the ground at the airline's hub, Keflavík International Airport in Iceland, can monitor, in real time, all kinds of data points involving one of its jets as the aircraft sits at the gate at Seattle-Tacoma International Airport, including whether its doors are open or closed or its engines are on or off.

The software, offered on a subscription model, monitors a lot more and also offers predictive analytics.

"Real time aircraft data over IP links opens up new opportunities to provide operational insight to airline operators," Schramm said. "Real time data can help managers decide to make costly diversions (to repair an aircraft experiencing trouble) or to allow jets to complete their flights."

Icelandair is in the final stages of implementing the iJet technology. That must wait until the airline's Icelandic regulators give their blessing, Schramm said.

Competition is emerging fast in this market.

A small venture firm based in Calgary, Alberta, called Flyth Aerospace Solutions, offers in flight software to airlines with an off-the-shelf product somewhat similar to iJet's, but it uses far more expensive Iridium satellite communications.

A second, much larger firm, Los-Angeles-based Global Eagle Entertainment, has also been moving fast, buying Emerging Market Communications Inc. of Miramar, Florida, for $550 million in May. EMC offers global satellite-based and broadband services to private and government customers in the aviation and maritime (yachts and ferries) markets.

As iJet tries to grow its business, Schramm says it may explore partnerships with other companies, such as aerospace hardware manufacturers and connectivity providers, to boost sales.

iJET TECHNOLOGIES INC.

Created: 2009

Founders: Jan Petter Roed and Bill Marks

CEO: John Schramm

Headquarters: Seattle

Number of employees: 17

Revenue:"None to some."

Major clients: Iceland Air is the early adopter; a second airline, not yet publicly unidentified.

-----------------

LESSONS LEARNED

Any company that starts from zero needs to start with a product. One of the struggles iJet had was a grand vision that wasn't well defined at the product level. Define what you're doing, but also what you're not doing.

Understand the sales cycle of the industry you are entering and make sure your investors do, too.

To be successful as an early stage company requires a team effort, so pick the team wisely. Empower people but don't over manage. Hires should be broadly competent people comfortable working through ambiguity. They must also be patient with other team members when things get hard.

Lure scarce talent not only with free lunches and perks, but hard sell the opportunity to do interesting, innovative work not typically available to new hires at big tech companies.

urn:contentItem:5XBT-8BB1-JBJ7-N4K5-00000-00I joined a tech start-up in 19982019-10-26T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:00:58ZLexisNexisI joined a tech start-up in 1998Rana Foroohar

In the late 1990s, pretty much anyone under 40 with loads of ambition wanted to be in the dotcom "space".

It was two decades ago, but I remember exactly where I was when I got the call. At the time, I was a mid-level magazine journalist, working in a dark, low-ceilinged office in midtown New York, spending hour upon hour rewriting prose sent in by correspondents from abroad. It was there, in my tiny office strewn with empty coffee cups, that I picked up the phone to a headhunter who told me that a group of London investors were keen to have me join them to build "scale" and "synergy" in the burgeoning European internet market.

I was breathless with excitement. In the late 1990s, pretty much anyone under 40 with loads of ambition wanted to be in the dotcom "space". The company I was being wooed by was a high-tech incubator called Antfactory, a start-up venture group comprising former investment bankers and emerging market investors, who were looking to scout - wait for it - "pan-European b-to-c media deals". In English, that meant internet media businesses that would produce content for consumers across the continent.

In retrospect, the fact that a bunch of rich guys with very little operational experience were willing to hire a journalist who had never worked in either technology or finance as a partner in their firm, and give her a six-figure salary and thousands of stock options, was clearly the sign of a market top. It didn't feel like it then, though. This was my opportunity to jump on the first dotcom bandwagon. And reader - I did.

I've thought about this period in my life a lot in recent years, as the technology sector has risen to ever-frothier heights. A record amount of money has been poured into the sector over the past decade. The advent of huge venture funds such as Japan's SoftBank has added fuel to the market. (SoftBank helped push up the value of WeWork, which ultimately pulled its IPO.)

Shares in once-touted unicorns such as Uber and Lyft have been falling. And yet, the money keeps flowing. One of the Valley's oldest and most respected funds, Bessemer, recently announced a new bucket of money to invest in later-stage start-ups that want to stay private longer, presumably to avoid the fate of WeWork. All this sounds very familiar to me.

At the turn of the millennium, the tech frenzy was still new. Internet usage was becoming the norm as connectivity improved. People were actually excited to use a Yahoo mail address. Amazon wasn't scary but cool, so much so that Jeff Bezos was named Time's 1999 "Person of the Year". It was the same year that Americans' online Christmas shopping doubled.

The tech market was different back then - frothy, yes, but also fresh. In retrospect, though, it also had much of the hype that I have felt in the technology sector over the past couple of years.

Then, as now, all asset classes had boomed in sync, fuelled by deregulation, loose monetary policy and too much debt. Tax relief had thrown kerosene on a hot market - one of the triggers for the dotcom bubble 1.0 was the Taxpayer Relief Act of 1997, which lowered the top marginal capital gains tax rate in the US from 28 per cent to 20 per cent, and in turn made more people more interested in becoming speculative investors.

Just like the 2017 Trump tax cuts, which mainly benefited large corporations, they aided an asset bubble but not much else; and the lion's share of the benefits went to a handful of firms and people.

Then, as now, too few people were thinking about experience, or long-term value, or even profits. They were looking for highly mobile young tech enthusiasts who could, as Uber co-founder Travis Kalanick would later put it, "always be hustling".

Antfactory's panglossian goal was to become the Idealab of Europe; a place where start-ups would be not only funded but also created and shaped. In those very-far-away-seeming days of "Cool Britannia", it somehow managed to persuade a range of companies including Citigroup to give them $US120 million to invest in European dotcom start-ups.

They found me because I had just written a cover story for Newsweek on Europe's internet boom. "Europe's Got Net Fever," screamed the headline. "The Symptoms Are Clear - Hot New Companies, Job Offers Featuring Ferraris and a Certain Swagger as Bright Young Businessfolk Stake Their Claims in Cyberspace."

Yes, it's a bit embarrassing to write these words now. If I had thought much about it, I'd have realised I was coming in as the roller-coaster was shifting into free fall. The covers of American news magazines have been proven to be a reliable counter-indicator of what's happening in the markets.

The slide began a little over a year after that cover. But there was still plenty of time to spin a story of building "scale" and "synergy" in the as-yet-fragmented European internet market. Unlike the US, which already had a base of 121 million users who spoke the same language and wanted to buy more and more of the same stuff online, Europe was a collection of countries, each with a unique culture and individual internet markets; the euro had only just been introduced. But optimism was the common language.

Antfactory, its founders touted, as they collected cheques from established investors in the City, would sit in the centre of it, leveraging these wonderful new economies of scale. It would find the best European dotcoms - in travel, in music, in finance, in health - and mash them together, boosting their global presence and stock valuations.

Exchanges from London to Frankfurt to Paris would compete to take these new companies public. Riches would be had by all. After all, why have six different travel-booking sites (serving France, Italy, Spain, and so on) when you could have one?

From where I sat, in my dingy Manhattan office, this was an appealing proposition. In the US, the migration from print publications to online was under way. At Newsweek, we were beginning to suspect our world wouldn't be the same for much longer. Free dinner was still served to editorial staff in the wood-panelled penthouse that had once been a conference room for General Motors. But the company had, to the dismay of the old-timers, finally started cutting back on the expense-able (and often excessive) drinking on the nights that we'd go to press. That, too, was the sign of a market shift.

So were the fortunes of people like Laurel Touby, one of the freelance writers for the last magazine I'd worked for, Working Woman. Laurel had left journalism to start up a networking group for creative types in online media. I remember once saying to her, "Laurel, you should really give up journalism and start a business." She did, growing her informal networking group into mediabistro.com, which cornered the market for media and PR job listings and was later sold for $US23 million. She promptly bought an apartment so stunning it was featured in The New York Times, and became a start-up investor.

The idea of trading in the punishing demands of reporting to partake of the riches of the internet was certainly on my mind as I considered Antfactory's offer. I loved being a journalist, but it offered a predictable trajectory: write more features, maybe become a senior editor or a columnist, watch my salary inch up by a paltry 2 per cent every year. Antfactory, on the other hand, offered something new and inherently appealing to a business journalist: the chance to get into the game, rather than just write about it. I told the Ants that I'd come to London to discuss the offer.

The partners, as it turned out, didn't know much more about technology than me. One had worked mostly in entertainment and luxury brands. Two others were London finance guys, including one whose family was big in Greek shipping. I was a good enough reporter to appreciate the shortcomings of the team.

Still, the idea of being able to waltz into a high-tech incubator as a partner and scout deals at the height of the dotcom boom was exciting. The stock options might actually be worth something. In a worst-case scenario, I told myself, I would go back to journalism knowing a lot more about the tech industry than I did before I worked in it.

I moved to London in December 1998 and plunged into the dotcom scene, where I soon encountered the European equivalent of Laurel's brainchild - a networking salon-cum-headhunting site called First Tuesday. It had been founded in part by Nick Denton, a former Financial Times journalist who would eventually go on to start Gawker, and a Silicon Valley transplant named Julie Meyer. Both of them were more businesspeople than technologists. The DNA of the London start-up scene reflected the DNA of the city itself: it was about money and dealmaking.

Of that, there was plenty. New jobs - and new companies - were being posted on First Tuesday's website every few minutes. At networking events, Denton and Meyer made it easy to see where the money was - potential investors wore red dots on their lapels; the "talent" wore green. The reds, who were rarer and inevitably more popular, would often emerge exhausted after fighting off eager greens over cheap wine and snacks. The group claimed that $US100 million worth of deals had been cut in this manner. I didn't really believe them, but I didn't entirely not believe them.

Either way, one thing was clear: there was money to be made. It was the roaring '90s after all, in London as well as in Silicon Valley. If the 1980s began the age of greed, then the late 1990s cemented it. It was the era of Bill Clinton and Tony Blair, who continued much of the market deregulation that had started under Reagan and Thatcher.

It was a period when the notion of retiring comfortably with a gold watch and a pension began to slip away, replaced by soccer moms reading Money magazine and hoping to become stockpicking millionaires overnight.(My own mother, a first-grade teacher, was - incredibly - dabbling in biotech stocks, an experiment which shaved 30 per cent off her retirement.)

Antfactory was, essentially, doing the same - dabbling in things nobody knew enough about. But it was clear to me that the people in charge didn't have the experience and insight to pull it off.

Most of the opportunities we were looking at were copycats of successful start-ups that had already launched, or ill-advised attempts to create internet arms of existing legacy brands. Although the founders kept a deal flow going and the press kept writing naively positive stories about London's homegrown tech incubator, internally the firm was already starting to revert to what it really was - a collection of ex-City bankers looking to make a quick buck.

When you pull back the lens, that's really what much of the late 1990s/early 2000s dotcom boom was all about. Far away in Silicon Valley, a handful of companies such as Google, Amazon and PayPal were carving out sustainable niches - and then ringfencing those markets. Then there was everyone else.

As Hal Varian, who would become Google's chief economist, put it in 2001: "The obvious corollary to winner-take-all is loser gets nothing, and there will inevitably be many more losers than winners."

True enough. But the frenzy of financial activity was being fuelled by more than just your typical market forces. In retrospect, it reflected the increasingly tight links between the world's financial capitals and tech hubs, and the halls of power in places like Washington and Brussels. The tech industry had lobbied successfully in the 1990s against new accounting standards that would have forced companies to mark the value of options on their books.

Today, companies such as Apple and Google can take advantage of ultra-low interest rates (which themselves were a response to the 2008 crisis) to issue loads of bonds on the US debt markets and then use the proceeds to pay back the richest shareholders in the form of tax preferential buybacks and dividends, further increasing the wealth divide.

Back in early 2000, a different problem was emerging - the dotcom boom was turning to bust. The value of the Nasdaq index peaked on March 10 2000. On March 20, Barron's ran a cover story entitled "Burning Up: Warning - Internet Companies Are Running Out of Cash, Fast." It's incredible how similar it seems to the negative sentiment around tech today.

Then, as now, companies were starting to issue reversals of revenue statements, and investors began to realise that many previously lauded start-ups were more style than substance. Once the Fed decided to raise interest rates, the die was cast. The "easy money" had officially run out. Or at least until it was time to reflate the market and create tech bubble 2.0.

By September 2001, Antfactory's investors had lost patience with the leadership, and demanded they return a $US120 million cash pile and wind down the firm. I often think about those disastrous years and wonder what has changed in the tech world - and what hasn't.

Today's tech market is so much more developed, with vastly better infrastructure and game-changing innovations such as ubiquitous smartphones. We are only just beginning to move into artificial intelligence, the internet of things, 5G and other areas that many businesses are counting on to propel revenue growth in the future. Certainly, it is harder for companies to receive funding just by sticking ".com" behind their names.

Still, there are many things about the current economy that remind me of my time in London. Then, as now, we were in the late stages of a credit cycle, with too much money chasing too little value.

Investors who were counting on a spate of hot IPOs to buoy the late stage of a boom market were disappointed. Back then, the infamous Pets.com went out of business nine months after its IPO.

The turning point this time may be Uber's IPO on May 10, one of the most anticipated in history but, in the end, a dismal failure. It marked a top in tech stocks that simply don't make any money, despite their size and disruptive power. Shares in any number of once-hot companies, like Lyft or Slack, have slumped. WeWork has, of course, cancelled its IPO, and seems to be bringing property prices in New York and London down with it.

It's only the beginning of what I suspect will be a long fall for Big Tech. From 2008 onwards, Silicon Valley took the place of Wall Street as the global hub of corporate wealth and power, creating the world's first trillion-dollar business, growing companies with more users than the planet's largest countries, and reshaping everything from our brains to our elections.

But just as finance faced an existential crisis a decade ago, so Big Tech is facing one now. The US-China trade and tech war is leading to a "splinternet," which will make it much more difficult for digital giants to grow. There are calls from regulators and politicians on both sides of the Atlantic to clamp down on the size and power of the sector.

I never made any money from those Antfactory shares. In fact, demoralised by listening to people try to make nothing sound like something, I left the company several months before it went bust. But I learnt a few things about bubbles along the way.

Antfactory, its founders touted, as they collected cheques from established investors in the City, would sit in the centre of it, leveraging these wonderful new economies of scale. urn:contentItem:5WNM-X4X1-F03R-N33J-00000-00'I Knew I'd Lose Some Friends' - Inside Co-Founder Chris Hughes' Campaign Against Facebook2019-07-27T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:00:58ZLexisNexis'I Knew I'd Lose Some Friends' - Inside Co-Founder Chris Hughes' Campaign Against FacebookZero Hedge

Jul 27, 2019( Phil's Stock World: http://www.philstockworld.com Delivered by Newstex) Courtesy of ZeroHedge[1]. View original post here[2]. We can imagine Mark Zuckerberg, sitting ensconced in his bunker inside Facebook HQ, reading every new story about his one-time friend and Facebook co-founder Chris Hughes' campaign to force the breakup of Facebook, the company Zuckerberg worked so hard to build. 'How ungrateful,' Zuckerberg probably thinks to himself. That's because Hughes has emerged as what the Washington Post[3] characterized as "one of [Facebook's] biggest problems." It started with a sweeping New York Times op-ed[4], where Hughes declared that Facebook 'should be broken up' and that while he still thinks Mark Zuckerberg is "a good, moral person", as Chairman and CEO of Facebook, Zuckerberg has too much power.

While Facebook gladly paid $5 billion to settle allegations of privacy violations with the FTC, the company is firmly opposed to any kind of anti-monopoly actions. Its argument is simple: Since consumers use social media apps that aren't controlled by Facebook (think Twitter and LinkedIn), it's clear that Facebook doesn't have a monopoly. And when asked about the status of his friendship with Zuckerberg after going public with his allegations, Hughes joked that Zuckerberg probably no longer considers him a friend. The decision to publicly oppose Facebook in the op-ed was a difficult one, he said. 'I knew I would lose some friends over it. And that's okay because some things are that important,' he said. 'But it's been nice on the other side of it, too, to have the argument out there, to speak my mind about what I think and believe.' In a story about Hughes' campaign to undermine the company he helped create, a company that netted him a fortune ($500 million at the time he cashed out his stake). Hughes left Facebook in 2007 to volunteer for the campaign of then-Senator Barack Obama. But now, according to WaPo[5], Hughes has been making the rounds on Capitol Hill, visiting dozens of lawmakers and regulators at the DOJ and FTC, and presenting a 39-slide PowerPoint deck that he purportedly made himself outlining his argument about Facebook being a monopoly. Hughes' argument depends on the vast user base of Facebook and Instagram, and the company's acquisitiveness, which helps to stifle competition by discouraging challengers. Facebook's wealth and power and massive user base have pushed it into monopoly territory, and its acquisitions of rivals have squashed competition. More than 2.7 billion people use Facebook or its other platforms, which include Instagram and messaging service WhatsApp, at least once a month, Facebook said Wednesday. "I hope that my speaking out provides cover to a lot of other folks, whether former employees or current ones, to express ambivalence or concern about what's going on," Hughes said in an interview Thursday. "And I think there's a lot to be concerned about." The former Facebook spokesman is also trying to convince other ex-employees with reservations about the company's largess to speak out. But the fact that a former executive are making these criticisms is a huge boon for trust-busters. It threatens not just Facebook, but the other tech giants of Silicon Valley. Hughes has effectively become the most effective lobbyist for the 'break up Facebook' crowd, and he's doing all of this work for free. And that's bad news for Facebook, because breaking up big tech has become a bipartisan issue, embraced by President Trump and Dems like Elizabeth Warren. To be sure, Hughes isn't the only former Facebook executive or early investor to criticize the company: Sean Parker and Robert McNamee and other former senior executives have also criticized Facebook over its business practices, but they haven't been lobbying for breaking up Facebook. Hughes has reportedly been a useful resource for anti-trust lawyers who have been working on a new argument for breaking up Facebook. Soon after, Hughes was contacted by two prominent antitrust scholars, Scott Hemphill of New York University School of Law and Tim Wu of Columbia Law School. The two academics and longtime collaborators had been developing an argument for breaking up Facebook in the form of the slide presentation. To them, the purchase of Instagram and WhatsApp represented a 'plain-vanilla violation of antitrust law, just low-hanging fruit,' Wu said in an interview. They began to pitch lawmakers and regulators together. Academics and lawmakers who have worked with Hughes say he has helped explain the motivations and viewpoints of key players at Facebook, including Zuckerberg - although Hughes says he has no specific insider knowledge. They say Hughes can frame the business practices of present-day Silicon Valley in ways that jibe with largely untested antitrust laws that were written for major oil and rail companies decades ago. [...] Hughes's feedback shaped the scholars' case, as he helped them understand how executives in Silicon Valley think about competition — it tends to be measured by viral growth rather than by size, said Hemphill, the New York University professor. At the time, the two professors were working on a roadshow, which they asked Hughes to join. Rhode Island Congressman David Cicilline say Hughes has helped inform his views about whether Facebook might be a monopoly. "The thing that stuck with mewas he focused on Facebook's revenue as a true measure of its role in the marketplace,' Cicilline recalled. "Facebook captures over 80 percent of all global social media revenue and controls 58 percent of the U.S. social media market. That's significant." So, how will Zuckerberg counter Hughes? The company has hired an army of lobbyists in the wake of its twin scandals, data privacy violations and its failure to stamp out fake accounts. But given his resources, Hughes is going to be a difficult critic to discredit and stamp out. urn:contentItem:5TY1-SFH1-JBCN-42MV-00000-00'I lead this company without political bias,' Google CEO Sundar Pichai to testify before Congress2018-12-10T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:00:58ZLexisNexisNEWS'I lead this company without political bias,' Google CEO Sundar Pichai to testify before CongressJessica Guynn

SAN FRANCISCO – First, Google's chief executive officer Sundar Pichai had an empty seat. Now he's in the hot seat.

In September, Google's parent company Alphabet refused to send its chief executive Larry Page or Pichai to testify before a Senate intelligence committee hearing. So U.S. senators set out a chair bearing Google's name and repeatedly took shots at the internet giant for being a no-show.

On Tuesday, Pichai will embark on a peacemaking mission in Washington with his first-ever appearance before Congress. He'll likely face the bipartisan backlash that has battered the internet giant's rivals like Facebook for months.

"We recognize the important role of governments, including this committee, in setting rules for the development and use of technology," Pichai will say, according to testimony posted Monday on the House Judiciary Committee's website.

The hearing before the House Judiciary Committee marks the beginning of a new political reality for Pichai, an engineer by training who grew up in Chennai, India, and is far more at home on Google's Mountain View, California, campus than on Capitol Hill. Once a darling of the Obama administration, Google is facing tougher scrutiny of its business practices and new threats of regulation from the Trump administration.

Lawmakers have held hearings in recent months discussing the need for stronger federal protections regulating the collection of people's personal online information. State attorneys general have also discussed alleged antitrust violations and Republican allegations of censorship of conservative voices.

Though the possibility of legislation to curb the power of tech companies still remains slim, with regulation-shy Republicans controlling the Senate, public statements from Democrats have increasingly put Google and others on the defensive.

Expected to top the agenda of Tuesday's hearing,"Transparency & Accountability: Examining Google and Its Data Collection, Use and Filtering Practices": Republican allegations of bias against conservatives in search results.

In his prepared testimony, Pichai tackled the allegations head on.

"I lead this company without political bias and work to ensure that our products continue to operate that way. To do otherwise would go against our core principles and our business interests," Pichai wrote. "We are a company that provides platforms for diverse perspectives and opinions – and we have no shortage of them among our own employees."

He also painted Google as a company that supports privacy legislation ("We have invested an enormous amount of work over the years to bring choice, transparency, and control to our users") and a company that has deep American roots, in anticipation of questions over Google's possible plans to re-enter the China search market with a product that censors results sensitive to Beijing.

Google abandoned that market in 2010 over concerns about censorship and government intrusion. A number of House Judiciary Committee members sent a letter to Pichai earlier this year demanding more information on the project codenamed Dragonfly. Facing a revolt from employees, Pichai has said Google has not yet decided whether to move forward with the search product.

Other topics will likely include Google's handling of user data and its handling of sexual harassment cases. More than 20,000 employees walked off the job in November to protest revelations in a New York Times article that the company quietly paid out millions to male executives accused of misconduct.

"Online technology is now an integral part of most Americans' modern lifestyle. It has globalized society and made it possible for people to connect across continents, explore vast amounts of information, and share meaningful dialogue with friends. However, the technology behind online services like social media and Internet search engines can also be used to suppress particular viewpoints and manipulate public opinion," House Judiciary Committee Chairman Bob Goodlatte (R-Va.) said in a statement. "Americans put their trust in big tech companies to honor freedom of speech and champion open dialogue, and it is Congress' responsibility to the American people to make sure these tech giants are transparent and accountable in their practices."

More: Google CEO Sundar Pichai to testify before Congress, answer questions on conservative bias

More: Google CEO Sundar Pichai bound for Washington as Trump takes aim at search engine

Until now, the internet giant has largely avoided heavy scrutiny from Washington even as concerns mount over its dominance of the search business around the world and the spread of disinformation and conspiracy theories on its YouTube video service.

That changed a few months ago when Google refused to send Page or Pichai, offering up Kent Walker, its top lawyer. Richard Burr (R., N.C.), who heads the Senate Intelligence Committee, rejected that offer. Instead, lawmakers grilled Facebook's chief operating officer Sheryl Sandberg and Twitter CEO Jack Dorsey about Russian election meddling, online privacy and political bias on tech platforms and then cranked up public criticism of Google.

A trip to Capitol Hill was hastily arranged. Pichai, 46, met with lawmakers from both parties, including a sit down with House Republican leader Kevin McCarthy, and agreed to appear before Congress.

Since then, Pichai has been working to solidify relationships with GOP lawmakers and conservative groups. Last week, he took part in a White House business roundtable that included other tech leaders such as Microsoft CEO Satya Nadella and Oracle co-chief executive Safra Catz.

President Donald Trump and his campaign manager, Brad Parscale, have accused Silicon Valley companies of liberal bias that has led to the suppression and censorship of conservative voices. In August, Trump claimed search results for "Trump News" were "RIGGED, for me & others, so that almost all stories & news is BAD." Google has repeatedly denied any political bias in Internet search results.

McCarthy had also chastised Google for search results, tweeting that results that incorrectly said the ideology of the California Republican Party included "Nazism" were a "disgrace." Google blamed "vandalism" at Wikipedia.

More: 'Fake social,' 'fake search' are the new 'fake news' as Trump attacks tech ahead of midterms

More: Trump says Google ignored his State of the Union address; Google disagrees

In his prepared testimony, Pichai emphasized the political diversity of Google employees. "Some of our Googlers are former servicemen and women who have risked much in defense of our country. Some are civil libertarians who fiercely defend freedom of expression. Some are parents who worry about the role technology plays in our households. Some—like me—are immigrants to this country, profoundly grateful for the freedoms and opportunities it offers. Some of us are many of these things," he wrote.

Censorship charges have been raised in multiple hearings on Capitol Hill against Silicon Valley tech companies. A recent poll from the Media Research Center conducted by McLaughlin & Associates found that 65 percent of self-described conservatives believe that social media companies intentionally censor the political right.

Until recently, lawmakers had focused their criticism on Facebook, after a series of privacy blunders and the unchecked spread of online propaganda by Russia agents during and after the 2016 presidential election. CEO Mark Zuckerberg testified on Capitol Hill in April.

Google was frequently mentioned during a meeting earlier this year with then-Attorney General Jeff Sessions and state law enforcement officials exploring potential antitrust and data privacy investigations.

Reports that Google employees debated ways to alter search results after the 2016 presidential election and an internal video obtained by right-wing news site Breitbart showing executives of Alphabet expressing dismay at the outcome of the presidential election added fuel to charges by the political right that Google is biased against conservatives.

"Recent reports suggest Google might not be wielding its vast power impartially. Its business practices may have been affected by political bias. Additionally, reports claim the company is compromising its core principles by complying with repressive censorship mandates from China," McCarthy said in a statement. "Mr. Pichai's scheduled appearance in front of the House Judiciary Committee is another important step to restoring public trust in Google and all the companies that shape the internet."

This article originally appeared on USA TODAY: 'I lead this company without political bias,' Google CEO Sundar Pichai to testify before Congress

urn:contentItem:5TY1-KDP1-JBCN-439G-00000-00'I lead this company without political bias,' Google CEO Sundar Pichai to testify before Congress2018-12-10T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:00:58ZLexisNexisUSA TODAY'I lead this company without political bias,' Google CEO Sundar Pichai to testify before CongressJessica Guynn

SAN FRANCISCO – First, Google's chief executive officer Sundar Pichai had an empty seat. Now he's in the hot seat.

In September, Google's parent company Alphabet refused to send its chief executive Larry Page or Pichai to testify before a Senate intelligence committee hearing. So U.S. senators set out a chair bearing Google's name and repeatedly took shots at the internet giant for being a no-show.

On Tuesday, Pichai will embark on a peacemaking mission in Washington with his first-ever appearance before Congress. He'll likely face the bipartisan backlash that has battered the internet giant's rivals like Facebook for months.

"We recognize the important role of governments, including this committee, in setting rules for the development and use of technology," Pichai will say, according to testimony posted Monday on the House Judiciary Committee's website.

The hearing before the House Judiciary Committee marks the beginning of a new political reality for Pichai, an engineer by training who grew up in Chennai, India, and is far more at home on Google's Mountain View, California, campus than on Capitol Hill. Once a darling of the Obama administration, Google is facing tougher scrutiny of its business practices and new threats of regulation from the Trump administration.

Lawmakers have held hearings in recent months discussing the need for stronger federal protections regulating the collection of people's personal online information. State attorneys general have also discussed alleged antitrust violations and Republican allegations of censorship of conservative voices.

Though the possibility of legislation to curb the power of tech companies still remains slim, with regulation-shy Republicans controlling the Senate, public statements from Democrats have increasingly put Google and others on the defensive.

Expected to top the agenda of Tuesday's hearing,"Transparency & Accountability: Examining Google and Its Data Collection, Use and Filtering Practices": Republican allegations of bias against conservatives in search results.

In his prepared testimony, Pichai tackled the allegations head on.

"I lead this company without political bias and work to ensure that our products continue to operate that way. To do otherwise would go against our core principles and our business interests," Pichai wrote. "We are a company that provides platforms for diverse perspectives and opinions – and we have no shortage of them among our own employees."

He also painted Google as a company that supports privacy legislation ("We have invested an enormous amount of work over the years to bring choice, transparency, and control to our users") and a company that has deep American roots, in anticipation of questions over Google's possible plans to re-enter the China search market with a product that censors results sensitive to Beijing.

Google abandoned that market in 2010 over concerns about censorship and government intrusion. A number of House Judiciary Committee members sent a letter to Pichai earlier this year demanding more information on the project codenamed Dragonfly. Facing a revolt from employees, Pichai has said Google has not yet decided whether to move forward with the search product.

Other topics will likely include Google's handling of user data and its handling of sexual harassment cases. More than 20,000 employees walked off the job in November to protest revelations in a New York Times article that the company quietly paid out millions to male executives accused of misconduct.

"Online technology is now an integral part of most Americans' modern lifestyle. It has globalized society and made it possible for people to connect across continents, explore vast amounts of information, and share meaningful dialogue with friends. However, the technology behind online services like social media and Internet search engines can also be used to suppress particular viewpoints and manipulate public opinion," House Judiciary Committee Chairman Bob Goodlatte (R-Va.) said in a statement. "Americans put their trust in big tech companies to honor freedom of speech and champion open dialogue, and it is Congress' responsibility to the American people to make sure these tech giants are transparent and accountable in their practices."

More: Google CEO Sundar Pichai to testify before Congress, answer questions on conservative bias

More: Google CEO Sundar Pichai bound for Washington as Trump takes aim at search engine

Until now, the internet giant has largely avoided heavy scrutiny from Washington even as concerns mount over its dominance of the search business around the world and the spread of disinformation and conspiracy theories on its YouTube video service.

That changed a few months ago when Google refused to send Page or Pichai, offering up Kent Walker, its top lawyer. Richard Burr (R., N.C.), who heads the Senate Intelligence Committee, rejected that offer. Instead, lawmakers grilled Facebook's chief operating officer Sheryl Sandberg and Twitter CEO Jack Dorsey about Russian election meddling, online privacy and political bias on tech platforms and then cranked up public criticism of Google.

A trip to Capitol Hill was hastily arranged. Pichai, 46, met with lawmakers from both parties, including a sit down with House Republican leader Kevin McCarthy, and agreed to appear before Congress.

Since then, Pichai has been working to solidify relationships with GOP lawmakers and conservative groups. Last week, he took part in a White House business roundtable that included other tech leaders such as Microsoft CEO Satya Nadella and Oracle co-chief executive Safra Catz.

President Donald Trump and his campaign manager, Brad Parscale, have accused Silicon Valley companies of liberal bias that has led to the suppression and censorship of conservative voices. In August, Trump claimed search results for "Trump News" were "RIGGED, for me & others, so that almost all stories & news is BAD." Google has repeatedly denied any political bias in Internet search results.

McCarthy had also chastised Google for search results, tweeting that results that incorrectly said the ideology of the California Republican Party included "Nazism" were a "disgrace." Google blamed "vandalism" at Wikipedia.

More: 'Fake social,' 'fake search' are the new 'fake news' as Trump attacks tech ahead of midterms

More: Trump says Google ignored his State of the Union address; Google disagrees

In his prepared testimony, Pichai emphasized the political diversity of Google employees. "Some of our Googlers are former servicemen and women who have risked much in defense of our country. Some are civil libertarians who fiercely defend freedom of expression. Some are parents who worry about the role technology plays in our households. Some—like me—are immigrants to this country, profoundly grateful for the freedoms and opportunities it offers. Some of us are many of these things," he wrote.

Censorship charges have been raised in multiple hearings on Capitol Hill against Silicon Valley tech companies. A recent poll from the Media Research Center conducted by McLaughlin & Associates found that 65 percent of self-described conservatives believe that social media companies intentionally censor the political right.

Until recently, lawmakers had focused their criticism on Facebook, after a series of privacy blunders and the unchecked spread of online propaganda by Russia agents during and after the 2016 presidential election. CEO Mark Zuckerberg testified on Capitol Hill in April.

Google was frequently mentioned during a meeting earlier this year with then-Attorney General Jeff Sessions and state law enforcement officials exploring potential antitrust and data privacy investigations.

Reports that Google employees debated ways to alter search results after the 2016 presidential election and an internal video obtained by right-wing news site Breitbart showing executives of Alphabet expressing dismay at the outcome of the presidential election added fuel to charges by the political right that Google is biased against conservatives.

"Recent reports suggest Google might not be wielding its vast power impartially. Its business practices may have been affected by political bias. Additionally, reports claim the company is compromising its core principles by complying with repressive censorship mandates from China," McCarthy said in a statement. "Mr. Pichai's scheduled appearance in front of the House Judiciary Committee is another important step to restoring public trust in Google and all the companies that shape the internet."

This article originally appeared on USA TODAY: 'I lead this company without political bias,' Google CEO Sundar Pichai to testify before Congress
